utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: -- at worst. Juan, what does your perfect day look like? Maybe baseball or with --?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Not a bad idea. But I mean, you know, my perfect -- I think one of the things that strikes me is family. I mean, I noticed that on this list is kindness. And so if I -- like, I have Sunday night dinner with my family, I always think, "This is great." You know, you catch up with everybody. You say hello. Everybody's there. So, you know, heaven is like you're surrounded by people you love. I think that's -- you know, hopefully, that's the family or maybe your friends. I don't know. But to me, that's pretty -- pretty good. I noticed also on this list, the things that entertain me. Like listening to rain. I like listening to rainfall. But I don't know if that makes for a perfect day. On the whole, I'd say it's easier to be perfectly happy if you live in San Diego. Because I was looking at this list. Like the beach, sunshine, outdoors.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Traffic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Perfect day? I wouldn't mind being in jail.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, house -- a house arrest.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: House arrest, because you have no options. You've got your meals, and you just read. I could -- I could do that.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Wouldn't you be bored, though?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But no tennis lessons.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No tennis lessons.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Jesse, perfect day, jail?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How about that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe for someone else, that's their perfect day. In jail.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: All right. Never mind. All right. We'll save that for later. All right. "One More Thing" is coming up next, so stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Time now for "One More Thing." Big fun, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, as people know. Let's go to this first. Shall we?

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Sports Corner

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Sports Corner."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows I'm a huge fan of golf. A lot of great golfers out there like that Jordan Woods character. Anyway, Claws McGuff is my favorite golfer. You may have seen him at the PGA Bret Baier International. There he is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He just scored a hole-in-one and then started doing a lap -- what do you call that? A pole dance. In the -- there are a lot of children out there. Don't be looking at this. Very suggestive. But this went on for quite a while, and that's basically all I have to say about this video, except that I found it on Twitter. So there are good things you can find on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I might be joining that Twitter club

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Claws McGuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. There was a contest, and it was about dogs on Capitol Hill and the Independent Journal Review has named its cutest dog. There was a vote. The winner is hank. Check out Hank. This is a boxer originally from Rock Springs, Wyoming. His owner is Cara Ahearn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's cute.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She is the chief of staff to Wyoming Congresswoman Liz Cheney. Big winner. When he isn't busy clowning around, Hank has been known to makes friends, like, with the Capital police. He helps all sorts of people. He even knows Vice President Dick Cheney. He's a really cute dog, Hank. I think he very much deserved to win. Congratulations to Cara.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Does he win barking rights? Get it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I got it.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Bragging rights.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It took me a minute. Took me a minute.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Really bad. Never mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, folks. You may have heard the saying, "Don't go chasing waterfalls." But if you're in China this summer, you've got to stop and see this one. Take a look. Yes, that's the biggest man-made waterfall in the world, and it's streaming off the side of a 22-story skyscraper. The waterfall plunges from the top floors of the building. And this isn't cheap. It costs more than a hundred bucks an hour just to provide electricity for the four pumps that push the water over the side.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think this is totally unnecessary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, there's a leak, and they're pretending it's a waterfall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: People call the cops and say they think there's a plumbing leak --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the cops have to come out regularly for this amazing waterfall. So --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: You'd probably have to use the restroom a lot if you're here --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan does love the sound of rain.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I do. That's a fact. Jesse, you're up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's hard to run away from the cops when you're on top of the cop car. Take a look at this. A man in the back of a Texas police cruiser kicked out a window and climbed into the roof as it sped along the highway. He stayed on the top of the car for miles until backup came, finally. And he was charged with evading arrest.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They could have just hit the brakes really fast.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait. Did they know --- did they know he was there?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think they probably had an idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. He got out of the car.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's how you get Jesse's hair. It's windswept.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Don't you remember, we had a guy -- wait, I think you had a "One More Thing" where a guy in Florida was hanging on the back or the front of a car.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, he had that, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's my beat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you even look at the "One More Things" before you get them?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We know you do, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. I'm very specific about --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like mine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Lisa.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, take a look at this. I think there's an image. No, that's not me. Don't look at me. All right. So at first look that may look like a zebra, but if you notice that years are a little floppy, you know, instead of the rounder ear is that you have of the zebra. So guess what? This is actually a donkey, and there is a zoo in Egypt that tried to pass a donkey off as a zebra. The photo has gone viral. Now the zoo is trying to deny it. And actually, I didn't even know about this, but this is apparently not the first time a zoo has tried to do something like that. There was a Gaza Zoo incident in 2009 --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Fake zoo.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: -- that also tried to pass donkeys off as zebras. And a Chinese zoo tried to pass off a Tibetan mastiff dog as an actually lion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Here's the thing.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I guess you can't put lipstick on a pig.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: NO. But you know what you can say at the zoo? You can see he self-identifies as a zebra.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. All the clubs will let him in. If he says he's a zebra, he's a zebra.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: He should go to Harvard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Or "Z" is a zebra.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Z-bra.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Z-bra.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: That's a donkey. That's a donkey.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what you would do, though, because it's fraud against children. The kid's going to grow up and --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: It was a student that caught it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: A student was like, "That's a bunch of you know what?"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He'll end up in stripes. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So yesterday -- yesterday, Jesse said that we should stop telling you to set your DVRs. Why was that, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do they have those anymore?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think they still have a machine that will allow you to tape "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The televisions do it themselves.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm saying, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The TV.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: TV set.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You should tape this show, folks. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Guess what? Mike Emanuel is in for Bret Baier. Hey, Mike.

utterances.speaker: MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Hey, Juan. Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You're welcome. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Juan Williams along with Lisa Boothe, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York, actually, a little later, in New York City, and this is "The Five." As you just saw, President Trump wrapping up a speech to steelworkers in Illinois just moments ago. He's also visited farmers in Iowa. That was earlier today.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We have his hat made up. Look at that. It's the John Deere colors, actually, but make our farmers great again. Isn't that great?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Basically, we opened up Europe. And it's going to be a great thing for Europe, and it's really going to be a great thing for us, and it's going to be really great thing for our farmers. After years of shutdowns and cutbacks, today the blast furnace here in Granite City is blazing bright, workers are back on the job, and we are once again pouring new American steel into the spine of our country.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Now, some people are saying one of the biggest problems for Democrats in 2018, this year, and 2020, the presidential election year, is the party's inability to develop a cohesive message to counter President Trump. In fact, an op-ed in the New York Times today foreshadows Trump winning reelection in 2020 due to the strong economy. Senator Elizabeth Warren, who is rumored to be a future possible opponent of the president, offered a much different approach than Trump. Here she is calling for higher taxes?

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.utterance: There was a time in a very prosperous America, an America that was growing a middle-class, and America in which working families were doing better generation after generation after generation, where the top marginal rate was well above 50 percent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, I think the president and Republicans want to talk about the economy, about the stock market doing well, they've had some trouble delivering the message on the benefits of a tax cut, but we see the president getting out there and this may be the message he wants to deliver going into the midterms.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: First of all, I want that green hat. That looks pretty good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait, wait, it would cover up our wonderful.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah, you did just got your hair cut.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Why waste the money if you do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think I agree. I think Trump needs to focus like a laser on the economy, and law and order, and judges, and keep hammering Democrats as socialist freaks who kneel during the national anthem. There are great headlines coming out of the economy. We're supposed to get an enormous GDP number tomorrow, maybe 3, 4, 5 percent. We've had three straight quarters of 3 percent GDP economic growth. And low unemployment, fantastic for everyone. And the tax cut has delivered a $2,600 cut to every family in this country. But there are areas of concern, the wages dipped a little bit the last quarter. They're still up 2.8 percent, where under Obama they were flat. And the trade deal is tough because, you know, you see some places like we're talking about, you know, you have steel companies closing, and then you have aluminum companies opening up. And what he did with the E.U. was actually very smart. I think what he did is he's saying for short term pain, we want long term gain. So he raised some tariffs and they came back begging yesterday. And they have a verbal deal and they're going to now drop the tariffs on nonindustrial goods, they're going to drop the tariffs on liquefied natural gas. We still have the auto tariffs in play which isn't good for Michigan and South Carolina. But, all in all, you know, the farm subsidies I think are good politics but bad economics. But it's just showing the trade partners, listen, we're going to soften the blow because you're not going to inflict any pain on us. And, in order to eventually bring down all trade barriers, and that's the goal, free and open and fair trade.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Dana, Jesse makes the case, I think, from the Trump perspective that you want your partners -- and I think the president said his favorite word is reciprocal.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Reciprocal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Reciprocal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But here's the thing, in the papers today it said, my little pony, Jack Daniel's, Coca-Cola, G.M., the farmers, and Whirlpool, all say, you know what, this is hurting us, hurting our profits.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is an -- I think that's one of the reason you saw the president, one, be conciliatory towards the E.U. yesterday. It's just good for our allies, for us to work together. They didn't actually agree to anything yesterday. They just agreed to stop fighting in public and to deal with the issues, and that's great because we need to fight as allies against countries like China. I think that the president is smart to get out of town. In the early years of the Bush administration, that first term, the economy was great. You could not get a lot of media coverage around it. Obviously, we are at war as well. The great thing for the president, if he wants good headlines is he had to go to these places, and watch where the president goes. He's to places where he can help vulnerable Republicans members. He went to Iowa today and Illinois. There's two members there, Republican, they are in very bad shape, and he wanted to go and help shore them up. He'll probably return to those places. The other thing I would say is -- that Wisconsin, Minnesota, and Michigan, all of his numbers there are really bad. And so, where these tariff issues should help should be there. They're not helping so much. So he's got to figure out how to turn that around. And by being conciliatory towards the E.U., he might be able to do that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg, how did you get back from Granite City so quickly?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Boy, you know what? Private plane.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And a tunnel. And a tunnel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A tunnel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, it's like -- looking at Liz Warren and other folks like Cory Booker, right now we have so much good news, so much good news, and the Dems are fixated on finding bad news. They're like those old, strange men on the beach with metal detectors, you know, that are walking too close to you. Yeah, hoping to find something, except they're misery detectors and they can't find any misery so they have to invent misery. In this case, Liz Warren wants to raise tax rates to 50 percent for people, for some people, and rollback the tax cuts. She's essentially a success extinguisher. She's looking at the economy like it's a fire and she wants to put it out. That's what she's doing. Here's what I worry about is that it might achieve something. What I've noticed is that -- we might be entering the second part of a political cycle that's been going on since the '60s. The Republicans come in and they fix things, and that allows the Democrats to come in and break things because there're things to be broken, and then you get the Republicans back into fix things because the Democrats broke things and then the Republicans fix things, and then, the public say, oh, now we can sustain more Democrats. So they come in to break things. And this goes back and forth. So Republicans fix, Democrats break. Republican fix, Democrats break. This has been going on since the 1960s. So now, Trump has fixed a half a dozen things, and everybody is going, and you know what, let's give those Democrats another chance. Let them break some stuff.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: We can't let them break it.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: To Dana's point too, you know, he is there because of vulnerable members of congress, but he's also talking to -- I think, key constituencies right now. Talking to steel workers and farmers because there are people that have felt the effects of this, you know, trade tariffs that are going back and forth. And so, I think his message to them, both with the farmers and the steelworkers, is I'm with you. I was with you because you were the forgotten men and women who President Obama left behind, and I'm standing with you now and I'm fighting for you. And so, I think it's really critical time for him to be sending that message, and also to be touting the fact that we have seen hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs added under President Trump. The economy is good. As Jesse pointed out, GDP growth tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: One quick question.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The deficit, because he's offering 12 billion in subsidies to the farmers. Even the farmers are like, boy, you know, with the tax cuts they didn't pan out and now this that blows up the deficit. It used to be a Republican thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's used to be -- was a Democrat thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I've said Republicans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. But the Democrats didn't care about deficit. You guys invented them.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I'm not down -- I'm not down with the bailouts, but I think President Trump can say that I'm fighting for you. And yesterday's press conference also came at a critical time for him to be able to say that, look, this is having a movement and effect.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. All right. Trump allies pushing to impeach Rod Rosenstein, but could the plan open the door for Democrats to go after President Trump? Boy, that's a big debate and it's next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Republicans are planning to impeach Rod Rosenstein. We'll see how that goes. Freedom caucus leaders are accusing the deputy attorney general of stonewalling their request for documents, but aren't finding the support they need right now. Meantime, a turn in what the president calls the Russia witch hunts. Special Counsel Robert Mueller is reportedly examining the president's tweets and a possible obstruction case. All right. So, I think, let's start with the Rosenstein situation, Dana. I think what they're asking for are the original documents that existed to justify the opening of this Russia-Trump probe, and they have not been able to find any of those documents. They've been stonewalled, and the subpoenas have not been respected. But it doesn't look like this thing is going to go anywhere, the impeachment deal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I don't think so. This is one of those ones where I'm like, yeah, yeah, yeah, because it's not going anywhere. And you could have Alan Dershowitz say it is the most shortsighted and I have to say stupid thing I have heard in a long time. You have -- basically what he's saying is we have Democrats and others saying impeach, impeach, impeach of the president, and that, obviously, looks ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that this -- Republicans, like 20 of them, saying OK impeach Rod Rosenstein over something that the justice department says is not necessary. Anyway, so, no, I don't think that's going anywhere.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: it could have been contempt. That might have been more of a stepping stone before impeachment. Greg, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I don't think I've heard a single person that had actually said this is a good idea.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: America, there is your proof. Juan is saying this is a good idea. Do not do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Good idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here's the big problem. Impeachment proceedings require hearings, which will be required to carry, all right? And these are going to be really boring, stupid hearings.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it will cut into "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It will cut.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It will cut into the monologue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It will cut into the monologue. There'll be no five. You'll miss Outnumbered, Fox & Friends, everything is gone. And all your favorite shows in other channels will be gone too. No Judge Judy, is she still around?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, she's making a lot of money. All right, Juan, what do you think about this, and what do you think about Mueller going after Trump's mean tweets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think it's the meanest. I think it's evidence or potential evidence of obstruction in what he's trying to do. But, to me, this is a wonderful political story. I mean, forget for a second impeachment. Impeachment -- I mean, that's so -- it's so petty and mean- spirited. I don't know. But, anyway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'll remember you said that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maxine Watters wants to impeach Trump. That's different.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Excuse me, these guys are the majority. They're in power, Greg. They can actually do this. But, of course, what you heard from -- even Speaker Paul Ryan is -- he doesn't support it, right?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But he also said that he is frustrated as well with the DOJ, and not providing the documents that have been subpoenaed and asked for. And we look at things like text messages that popped up in the I.G. report that were never given to congress. So I think it's perfectly fair for Republicans that are conducting these investigations to be frustrated with Rod Rosenstein. And so, I think the point of this is to stir some sort of action, to put pressure on leadership, put pressure on the DOJ and Rod Rosenstein. Look, you've got to have the numbers for impeachment and they don't have that in the house. You're not going to have it moving forward if anything happened in the house to the senate. So, I mean, the numbers aren't there. So, I think the point is to put pressure, and congress really doesn't have a lot of tools at their disposal. You look at contempt, what did that do with Eric Holder, absolutely nothing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, Lisa, this is not high crimes and misdemeanors. No law has been broken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's what they're trying to find out. What they're looking for, Juan, are the documents that shows how did the investigation begin? Was there probable cause? Was their intelligence?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And they're looking at, when they issue the FISA warrant, was proper FBI protocol followed? No, they didn't. They're also looking for what was redacted from the FISA warrant. And the fact that Rosenstein hasn't come forward and say, here you go, because you guys have proper oversight, makes people think why isn't this guy playing ball?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is such a mistake, which is let it die. Let it go away.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, my camera is out. I don't know where to look.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The house is now out for five weeks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm running for congress.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Sending money, the Super PAC is over here. Mark Zuckerberg be out at Facebook, we'll found out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Some big problems brewing for big tech, President Trump taking aim at twitter over its reported shadow banning of some prominent conservatives, the social media platform under fire for allegedly restricting Republicans' visibility in search results. The president vowed to look into what he called the illegal practice. Though, Twitter officials describe it as a glitch they're trying to fix. And Mark Zuckerberg is on the hot seat after his company loses over 100 billion, with a B, dollars in value in the wake of its mounting scandals. Facebook shareholders have reportedly filed a proposal to remove him as chairman. Is that too extreme, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I mean, this is very interesting to coin a phrase. I think with social media, the bloom has come off the rose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's a great saying. I think that will really catch on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah. I'm going to quote, this is the greatest thing ever said about social media. Walter Kurt tweeted this last night, he said if twitter sells you conflict, Instagram sells you envy, and Facebook simply sells you. And I think -- if you think about that, people are starting to figure it out. You get on twitter, you get angry. When you get on Instagram, you get jealous. And when you're on Facebook you feel like you're being manipulated. And I think there's time to like -- these things have grown very quickly. Pull back, take a day off, twitter. Figure out, should you ban anonymity? Could that change twitter? If everybody's name was attached, that would be a start.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then you would know -- I mean, the shadow banning thing, Lisa, what do you think about it? I mean, the liberals sort of caught on last week to this issue and they said that conservatives are being favored by Facebook and they got headlines out of that.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, I thought was most illuminating is Jonathan Swan of Axios who, I think, did a great job doing reporting. But he said that, basically, conservatives have been coming to him for a while now and saying that stuff like this was going on and he never believed it. And what's interesting is now that it was reported in Vice, which is a liberal publication, people might actually take it seriously. So, I thought that was sort of illuminating. But regarding Facebook, they made, basically, the biggest mistake of all which was getting caught in President Trump's orbit and all of this Russia stuff because Facebook, basically, was like Teflon until that hit, and now they're dealing with the carnage and the damage of it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I know what Facebook did wrong, they messed with Diamond and Silk. That is the problem. That's why you see their market value plunge it's the curse of Diamond and Silk. In all seriousness, though, I would buy Facebook. I mean.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's what I wonder. I mean, I know nothing about how they do those things, but.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Buy and sell stock?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Call your broker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't really have one. I don't. But, I have -- I don't know, it's like a mutual fund, but whatever. Is it now a good time to buy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would buy. I mean, it's way down. It's a great company, and Zuckerberg is a genius, and he aced the Capitol Hill hearing. I think he's a really smart guy. He's got a little bit right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're looking for a job, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, if he ever writes a book, he must. Juan, you tell me, is it too extreme to say that Zuckerberg should be out of the job?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it's crazy. You know, he created this -- I mean -- and also, remember, I think Jesse said this to me just a moment ago. He said, you know, the only way that you can justify losing that much money is you made even more money. And he's made a lot of money for a lot of people. And I don't think Facebook is going away, but I think it's going to change. I think one of the things that I'd like to see change is they and this pretense that they are neutral platform. They're not neutral. They have to make decisions. And they should, in fact, censor some of the hate speech. I mean, people from Sandy Hook whose children were --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're trying to use a mix of people but also algorithms to do that, and it's frustrating.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but the algorithms are what got them in trouble yesterday, because people said, "Oh, some of these Republicans drop things that automatically drop when you click. It isn't quite working." And then they said it was the algorithms. But --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But the problem is the people that create the algorithms are usually politically-correct whiz kids. And there's bias baked into that cake. If you're designing an algorithm that says conservative speech is more akin to hate speech than liberal speech, automatically, it's going to be a biased against conservatives.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Maybe -- maybe if that's what you see, you have to watch this carefully. Because I side with you. I want free speech. But I'm going to tell you, hate speech, bullying, harassment, intimidation, that should not be --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But the problems are the fake stuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The whole fake stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They'll have to get rid of The New York Times.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Ben Sasse did the best job --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But Ben Sasse asked Mark Zuckerberg to try to define hate speech, and he stumbled and struggled with defining it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So I think that's a problem.

utterances.speaker: But my favorite -- my favorite tweet. There's a Reason reporter that tweeted after the Senate hearing and said that Mark Zuckerberg has every millennial's worst fear
utterances.utterance: trying to explain technology to the nation's elderly. Because that was part of why he did so well at the hearing is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, a lot of the people complaining are not elderly -- Eric.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: With all due respect.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hate speech -- hate speech, sorry to say, is in the eye of the beholder.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And it depends who's in charge. And they're going to say that "You're being mean to me." So that's why the -- the problem with hate speech is that it's subjective.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like art.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is. It is. And the other thing, too, is I don't think people understand algorithms. You know, just because someone is using an algorithm on you isn't wrong. They're -- like everybody does A-B testing with companies. Let's say -- let's say McDonald's. They'll try McRiblets in one place but not in another place. That's A-B testing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: McRiblets?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're fantastic. I'm sorry, that's Applebee's. So what happens is they're test -- when they test algorithms, oftentimes they test them on some people and see how it works. Dating sites do this a lot. They will test a dating algorithm. And people will go, "Well, I want -- you know, I want the other thing." Well, this could be better. So algorithms, it's not -- it's not wrong to use an algorithm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have an idea. You should create for "The G.G. Show" a character named Al Gore Rhythm.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Al Gore Rhythm. I think I did once.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My gosh. Harvard takes the sisterhood out of sorority, and Greg explains the Ivy League's co-ed controversy next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They cut that song out pretty -- pretty early. All right. A Harvard sorority just announced they're going gender neutral. Kappa Alpha Theta, if that's their real name, will actually be changing its name, delinking itself from its national chapter, all because Harvard penalizes its members by withholding student leadership positions, as well as other perks while still charging them, of course, 60 grand a year.

utterances.speaker: I know
utterances.utterance: It's hard to care about a Harvard sorority. Talk about a rough life. But it's a slow news day. And clubs -- and clubs, by nature, are clubby. People join based on shared traits, hobbies and so on. If you like stamps, you join a stamp club. If you like motorcycles, you join the Hell's Angels. In high school, I couldn't join the boys' chorus, because I couldn't sing. And I couldn't join the girls' chorus, because I went to an all-boys school. I could only sing in the shower, often by myself. It was pure hell, but I managed. But the irony of forcing inclusivity on clubs is that inevitably, clubs go away. It's not worth the trouble. Society is now in a gender panic where it's scandalous to say that boys and girls are different and that they like different things. I've yet to run into a single male who likes Maroon 5.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think you see my point there. And so, social circles will likely fold to pressure from self-serious college administrators. Maybe that's why everyone prefers to live on social media, for maybe it more closely resembles real life with friends, enemies, insults, jokes, insights, and genius. And it's 60-grand a year cheaper. Is it true, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that that's true. You make a very good point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Thank you very much. I wish I knew which one it was.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, that people like to be in a club, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because if you're on social media, remember, it was just last week that that actor, Duplass, whatever --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- got in trouble with all of his friends and his club, because he said, "Maybe if you want to follow somebody that might not totally agree with you, try Ben Shapiro."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then his club wanted to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Club him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also, a huge concern for people right now is the destruction of civil society.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And part of that is that people don't belong to clubs --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We need clubs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Rotary Club, things like this. People would get together and do things. Put on the parade. Have the event. Come help assimilate immigrants, things like that. This is actually a very interesting point that you made.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. You know, Juan, OK, there are other -- there are black fraternities. You would -- people would go crazy if you tried to say, "OK, black fraternities have to accept white people. Or gay fraternities have to accept straight people." I mean, a sorority is -- is a sorority a sorority anymore if it is gender-neutral?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I guess.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think its roots are as a female organization.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I mean, so much of this is kind of reactionary, if you will. I mean, like, you were talking about black fraternities, black sororities. Guess what? They were created because they weren't --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Black people were not allowed into the white ones.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And with the women's thing, it's interesting. You know, the male fraternities are the ones, especially at places like Harvard, Princeton, Yale. They're the ones that have all the tradition and the power and the secret societies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Skull and Bones.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And women, for the longest time, were saying, "Hey, how come we can't get in?" I mean, you know, Radcliffe, right, was the girls' school. And Harvard, the boys' school. Remember, all that has shifted. So we've seen changes. And for the most part, I think it's good, Greg. I think that you should be able to go. But the worry would be that -- and I think you hear this from a lot of women who argue that you need women's schools, women's colleges. Because that's where women get to be stronger.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: It's so stupid. It's so dumb. If someone wants to start a club and everyone calls themselves a "Z," why not? You do your thing. Why can't I be a part of a sorority, and we're all "she's"? I just think that this is so stupid. And I also think it just underscores and demonstrates the totalitarianism of the left, in the sense that they don't like something, they shut it down. We were saying this with free speech, as well, now with free association. And I think it's a big problem. And I just think it's -- I just think it's so stupid. I don't even have the words for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I liked being in a sorority in college. Lay off.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They didn't shut it down.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: No, but they're penalizing you to a point where it makes it very difficult to try to be a part of one. For making -- they're coercing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you remain closed. You should be open.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Exactly. So you can no longer be a sorority or a fraternity. Therefore, if you do, it's a single-gender organization. Then you get punished by the administration through things like --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Single-gender.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, through things like barring people from holding --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, right, right. But Lisa --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: -- leadership positions, things of that nature. How is that fair?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can still be open. You can still be in a sorority.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: People join another club. And everyone can be whatever you want to be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: We can all be unicorns. I don't care.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Leave unicorns out of this. Jesse, we keep hearing about how important it is to have safe spaces. Couldn't you argue that a sorority is a safe space for women? And fraternities are -- I mean, it's -- it's kind of strange.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Men kind of wouldn't mind living with women, but women do not want to live with men. We're disgusting, and we're loud and obnoxious, and we're going to be making all kinds of loud noises in the middle of the night. They need their space to be girls. Guys don't necessarily need that. We just, like, spread out --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and do our thing. This is why I didn't go to Harvard. I mean, this is -- you know -- what's so funny? What's funny? I don't know why everyone is laughing. I would also like to apologize on behalf of the "The Five" to Adam Levine. I think he's a good singer and I like Maroon 5.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: You did raise your hand. Everyone at home, he raised his hand when -- on the Maroon 5 point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I think it's about busybodies. This is one -- it's like the straws. And it's like there's a lot --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There was no one complaining.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There was so much good news. They have nothing left to complain about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Go after sororities. Well, I think we all learned a lesson here. That Jesse has terrible taste in music. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You do. Come on, Maroon 5? Do you actually listen to that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Listen, you thrash metal in the bump-in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, Iron Age.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everyone in the audience whose ears was bleeding.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Check out Iron Age. They have one album. It's very good. Iron Age is music. Maroon 5 --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Was someone running over a trash can?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think Iron Age was actually not very good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, it was great. Jeez, give them a chance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In the Iron Age.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OH, in the Iron Age. very funny. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Corny jokes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Corny jokes. Next, we reveal the secrets to an absolutely perfect day. That includes watching me. Don't go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: That song worked. All right. Well, we all know that watching "The Five" makes your day perfect. And now there may be scientific proof to back it up. A new study says the average person has only 15 perfect days a year. The ideal day recipe includes waking up at 8:15 in the morning, sunny skies with 74 degrees temperatures, enjoying about three hours outdoors, spending several hours with family and friends, and then winding [SIC] in front of the TV, and going to bed around 10:50 at night. So what does a perfect day look like for my fellow "Fivers"? All right. Well, my perfect day is the beach, hanging out, activities, may be a glass of wine, family, friends, and then some me time. Yes, there's -- I was with a stingray. I don't know if there's any other photos. Yes, that's it. All right. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you like to be with stingrays?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: At the beach.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a perfect day?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: All right, whatever. Jesse, what does your perfect day that is acceptable for national television?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. Wow. I mean, I sit next to Dana, so every day is a perfect day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Aww.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Aww.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're so charming. I can't stand it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like lying around in the pool, maybe, or you know, at the beach. That's a perfect day for me right there, on a unicorn --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hey.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A drink, catching some sun, not a care in the world.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: All right, Dana, so petting a dog was part of the mood boosters for people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. 1. No. 1.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: What is -- I assume your perfect day is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, I've got one. I have to have a schedule. So I like an early morning wake up, and I like to read all the papers. And then I like a long walk on the beach or wherever I am with Peter and Jasper, the dog. Jasper's the dog. I like a chance to read my books. I like to have a tennis lesson. Then I like to have a walk in the afternoon. Then I like to go to dinner. I like to have a game, like game night, and then I like to go to bed early.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: That's like four perfect days for me in one. Greg, what does your perfect day look like?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: First I throw up from hearing everybody else's perfect day. Jeez Louise. All right. You have to be an idiot to believe in perfect days. Wisdom comes from understanding the imperfections of life and appreciating when certain things come together. That's a good day. Never a perfect day. Here's the secret to a perfect day or a good day. Right? You are two different people. Right? You're two different people. I'm today Greg. But there's tomorrow Greg. If I really want to be mean to tomorrow Greg, I could drink a lot tonight and then -- and not do any work for tomorrow's show. And then tomorrow's Greg will have a hangover and be behind in work. So the key to a happy life is today Greg always has to be nice to tomorrow Greg. That's the secret to everything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not drinking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's why I like to go to bed early.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, that's what I'm saying, is everything is -- you are two people. You are today and you are tomorrow. And the only way you're going to have a perfect day or a good day is to work for tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I love it.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: That sounds like a good stretch. Because maybe if you have a perfect day, you really push it. The next day might not be a good day or a bad day --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: -- at worst. Juan, what does your perfect day look like? Maybe baseball or with --?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not a bad idea. But I mean, you know, my perfect -- I think one of the things that strikes me is family. I mean, I noticed that on this list is kindness. And so if I -- like, I have Sunday night dinner with my family, I always think, "This is great." You know, you catch up with everybody. You say hello. Everybody's there. So, you know, heaven is like you're surrounded by people you love. I think that's -- you know, hopefully, that's the family or maybe your friends. I don't know. But to me, that's pretty -- pretty good. I noticed also on this list, the things that entertain me. Like listening to rain. I like listening to rainfall. But I don't know if that makes for a perfect day. On the whole, I'd say it's easier to be perfectly happy if you live in San Diego. Because I was looking at this list. Like the beach, sunshine, outdoors.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Traffic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Perfect day? I wouldn't mind being in jail.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, house -- a house arrest.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: House arrest, because you have no options. You've got your meals, and you just read. I could -- I could do that.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Wouldn't you be bored, though?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But no tennis lessons.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No tennis lessons.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Jesse, perfect day, jail?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe for someone else, that's their perfect day. In jail.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: All right. Never mind. All right. We'll save that for later. All right. "One More Thing" is coming up next, so stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Time now for "One More Thing." Big fun, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, as people know. Let's go to this first. Shall we?

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Sports Corner

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Sports Corner."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Everybody knows I'm a huge fan of golf. A lot of great golfers out there like that Jordan Woods character. Anyway, Claws McGuff is my favorite golfer. You may have seen him at the PGA Bret Baier International. There he is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He just scored a hole-in-one and then started doing a lap -- what do you call that? A pole dance. In the -- there are a lot of children out there. Don't be looking at this. Very suggestive. But this went on for quite a while, and that's basically all I have to say about this video, except that I found it on Twitter. So there are good things you can find on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I might be joining that Twitter club

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Claws McGuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. There was a contest, and it was about dogs on Capitol Hill and the Independent Journal Review has named its cutest dog. There was a vote. The winner is hank. Check out Hank. This is a boxer originally from Rock Springs, Wyoming. His owner is Cara Ahearn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's cute.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She is the chief of staff to Wyoming Congresswoman Liz Cheney. Big winner. When he isn't busy clowning around, Hank has been known to makes friends, like, with the Capital police. He helps all sorts of people. He even knows Vice President Dick Cheney. He's a really cute dog, Hank. I think he very much deserved to win. Congratulations to Cara.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Does he win barking rights? Get it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I got it.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Bragging rights.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It took me a minute. Took me a minute.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Really bad. Never mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, folks. You may have heard the saying, "Don't go chasing waterfalls." But if you're in China this summer, you've got to stop and see this one. Take a look. Yes, that's the biggest man-made waterfall in the world, and it's streaming off the side of a 22-story skyscraper. The waterfall plunges from the top floors of the building. And this isn't cheap. It costs more than a hundred bucks an hour just to provide electricity for the four pumps that push the water over the side.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think this is totally unnecessary.

utterances.utterance: It's hard to run away from the cops when you're on top of the cop car. Take a look at this. And he was charged with evading arrest.

utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.utterance: I like mine.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, take a look at this. I think there's an image. No, that's not me. Don't look at me. All right. So at first look that may look like a zebra, but if you notice that years are a little floppy, you know, instead of the rounder ear is that you have of the zebra. So guess what? This is actually a donkey, and there is a zoo in Egypt that tried to pass a donkey off as a zebra. The photo has gone viral. Now the zoo is trying to deny it. And actually, I didn't even know about this, but this is apparently not the first time a zoo has tried to do something like that. There was a Gaza Zoo incident in 2009 --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fake zoo.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.utterance: That's right. All the clubs will let him in. If he says he's a zebra, he's a zebra.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
